awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Multi-Sensory Therapy To Improve Lives of Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase II project will develop a multi-sensory social skill program to improve the lives of children who have been diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Currently, ASD is the fastest growing developmental disability in the US, with 1 in 59 children being affected. It is well established that children with ASD struggle with their social skills, which negatively affects the child's ability to make friends and integrate into the community and create their best life. Current interventions are expensive, time consuming, and parents, teachers, and therapists are seeking better solutions. This project will address these issues through the development of an affordable, time efficient application. The application will greatly improve social skills while also addressing sensory integration, anxiety, and self-esteem. As research continues and the product is refined, it will be broadened to all ages, targeting the ~5 million individuals with ASD in the US, and the ~74 million worldwide. Additionally, this project can be adapted to help non-ASD children who struggle with social skills or have developmental disabilities. Using the program in both homes and schools, creates a strong commercial impact, leading to a self-sustaining business. 


The technical innovation of this project is an educational application developed for smart mobile devices, improving social skills for children diagnosed on the autism spectrum. This novel technology incorporates and combines proprietary source code, customizable features, integration of original music, video, facial recognition technology, and tracking tools to create a powerful modeling, learning, and practicing environment. The technology is the only social curriculum designed to allow students to learn and practice the social skill independently, or with other human interaction; including the ability to have multiple devices sync together, allowing practice to take place between participants in real time. The research goal is to develop and test an application, which teaches children with autism spectrum disorder to improve and generalize social skills to familiar and unfamiliar people. This will be accomplished through software development, which will include integration of video and music, testing for program glitches, compatibility with various devices, and technology that can be implemented in a one-to-one or group setting. A pilot study will include an intervention vs. control design to assess the effectiveness and user ability of the program with students in grades K-6 with varying degrees of autism, thus validating the need and effectiveness of the program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is one of the fastest growing developmental disabilities in the US. ASD is a neurodevelopmental disability that impairs an individual's ability to communicate and interact with others. Although the cause of ASD is still a mystery, scientists continue to make progress in finding links to this social impairment. If these links are indeed associated with ASD, integrating these findings into a social skill program will create a better solution with better outcomes, a task that Teaching It Right, LLC is set to accomplish.  

NSF grant funding supported Teaching It Right's goal to develop a social skill program to improve the lives of children on the autism spectrum. Their program teaches social skills, sensory integration, and builds self esteem. This 10-minute a day program is fast, fun, and easy to use. The program is composed of 20 social skills and teaches skills through video modeling, music learning, and  interactive practice.

Teaching It Right tested their program, We Are Friends, with 69 students on the autism spectrum. Participating students were in both the "Functional Skill Classes" and the "Resource Classes" in 1st-6th gade. The intended outcome for students who used the We Are Friends program was an increase in communication skills with their peers and adults. Given a pre vs post, intervention vs control design, results showed that students who used We Are Friends had a statistically significant improvement in communication skills vs students who did not use the We Are Friends program. Communication skills included being able to greet another person, answer a question, ask a question back, respond to their answer, and close the conversation.

Additionally, Teaching It Right had parents, teachers, and students fill out a survey to determine if they felt the students made improvement in the 20 social skills that were taught, along with increased self-esteem, confidence, and sensory integration. Survey results showed parents, teachers, and students who used the We Are Friends program made greater improvement in all areas addressed than students who did not use the program. Parents, teachers, and students saw the greatest improvements in self-esteem, confidence, communication skills, and self-regulation. 

Teaching It Right is pleased with the results of this study and is confident this program will be effective for individuals with autism. Those who received the most consistent intervention excelled. Improvement in social skills lays a strong foundation in building relationships, preparing to become a self-sustaining adult, and empowering children for future success.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/16/2022
Modified by: Andrea F Johnson
